comments.commentBody: With all the international activities of U.S. banks, it's incomprehensible that they didn't foresee and act to prevent this problem.  Perhaps the bank CEO's were too busy counting their bonuses to attend to business.

I don't see a bright future for Thailand. The people have voted for levels of corruption beyond their comprehension. Voters are bribed here. It's never discussed in popular media unfortunately and should be. It's not about the people choosing. There is no idealism involved here. Weeks leading up to the election Pheu Thai representatives targeted every district in the entire country offering varying amounts of money for votes. I was offered 500 baht, less than USD20. In a country where minimum wage is 150 Baht a day, that's significant. Thaksin will return and more uprisings will likely ensue, unless he successfully bribes enough people. It's very sad when individuals can wield enough power to manipulate the thoughts of the easily-persuaded masses and the mass media translates that into some "the people have spoken" concept. My heart goes out to the people of this country.

Besides the excellence of play by the men's top trio of Djokovic, Nadal, and Federer, is the fact that are all very gracious players as well. This is in wonderful contrast to the days of McEnroe and Connors, who were really mean-spirited in their playing days.

McEnroe is a pretty good tennis commentator, but every time I hear him it makes me wish they'd kicked him out of a tournament for bad behaviour back in his playing days -- the sports organizers never seemed to realize that McEnroe needed them much more than they needed McEnroe. But I digress.

Mr. MacDonald, I so enjoy reading your posts. As an avid tennis fan, I find your analysis fascinating and always educational. Thank you, and I look forward to reading your analysis of the US Open matches next month.
NBC contaminates the coverage on any sport they get their corporate hands on.  Keeping them away from tennis can only be good.
I don't have cable but still say good riddance to NBC.  They insulted the event, the sport and the fans by playing semifinal matches on tape delay.

Thanks, Geoff: very interesting analysis of Djokovic's technique.

Last September, when he got his 10th major at the US Open,,I thought that Rafa had a good chance to match or surpass Federer's 16 grand slams. With Nole's rise, I think the odds of that get much longer. Though Rafa will still own the French for the foreseeable future, it will be much tougher for him to bag the other three majors while Djokovic is playing well, and even more so with Del Potro, Murray, Tomic and maybe Raonic in the mix.
Thank god! NBC is stuck in the last century and didn't deserve the contract. Hopefully most tennis fans have either cable or internet access and ESPN will do just fine.

NBC gave us clean unencrypted HDTV video, available on standard cable and over the air.

This is very bad news.

But at least ESPN will keep us up to date on irrelevant news with their bottom (of the barrel) line scroll bar. Makes for lousy video, but what the heck, we tennis fans need to know the latest sports gossip.

Thanks for selling out Wimbledon.
How do you beat Novak?  Ask federer!

Very good analysis. Tennis is about matchups from the 3.0 to the elite level. Nadal's game does not bother Djokovic because the latter does almost everything a little better. Federer poses a different set of challenges for Djokovic. Even so Federer must still play a great match and serve lights out to win. The one big difference between the finalists was that Nadal just was able to get Djokovic's serve back in play whereas Djokovic handcuffed Nadal to the baseline with his returns. So Djokovic controlled most of his service points but Nadal seemed to start out even. I thought that was a big difference in the match.

To Novak my congratulations for this great win having reached the number one product of perseverance, discipline, talent and intelligence.
Rafa, my admiration for your professionalism, integrity and sportsmanship, you are and you will be a giant in the world of tennis. Thank you both for giving us these lessons of fighting spirit and sportsmanship. God Bless them.

#4 Lisa: You have a computer? Watch it streaming on ESPN3 or use one of the offshore sites like atdhe.net. I watched the BBC's coverage live through atdhe.net today -- a real treat. Their commentators do not blather away while the ball's in play.

Wow. One week into SSM, and this article advocates exactly what opponents predicted. So much for the canard that extending marriage to same sex couples will only "strengthen" marriage by extending the social benefits of the institution to a new class of "families."

By definition, our public policy regarding marriage must relate to the public interest. There is a strong public interest in encouraging stable, self-reliant families, where children are raised by committed parents and each family member can rely on the others to do their part and make sacrifices for mutual good. There is no public interest in recognizing marriage as a way to make couples feel good about "validating" their relationship or maximize their private sexual pleasure.

A quote attributed to Savage is revealing: “I acknowledge the advantages of monogamy when it comes to sexual safety, infections, emotional safety, paternity assurances. [Note: nothing about public interest in providing for children and avoiding the social cost of failed families.] But people in monogamous relationships have to... acknowledge the drawbacks of monogamy around boredom, despair, lack of variety, sexual death and being taken for granted.”

Savage has it backwards. Marriage is not about maximizing sexual pleasure. Sex is about creating and nurturing a family. It's hard work to stick with a marriage for life, "for richer or poorer, in sickness or in health." A marriage is making and keeping commitments to each other, to extended family, and to society to stay the course and take care of your own, even though it inevitably involves personal sacrifice, humility, and not always having it your way. When couples make and keep these covenants, society is better off. That is the public interest behind marriage.

Compare these values to what Savage laments: the risk that you might at times suffer from "boredom", "lack of [sexual] variety" or (horrors!) "being taken for granted." All private interests.
So while California requires huge amounts of non energy producing "green energy" initiatives it let's vital infrastruture fall apart, anyone hear "democrats".

I thought this was a very well thought out article. It did not seem to endorse infidelity so much as highlight the fact that monogamy does not work for every couple.

What I felt was missing was a real analysis of what happens to that 3rd party with whom one has "meaningless" sex. Can that person be a victim who would like a more "traditional relationship?" The article references the historical practice of concubinage and mistresses. But concubines in many places had a significant role and their offspring could, at times, inherit the throne. Sure when embarking on a spouse approved infidelity one may easily find a partner ready for a no strings attached fling. What if they don't? What if emotions feelings change? I would have liked to see a thoughtful discussion of this aspect of the non-monagoumous marriage.

While infidelity in its many forms may not be a deal breaker for some marriages, I see such hypocrisy in the following:

Men aspire to be known for accomplishing difficult goals and achievements, except when it comes to sleeping with one woman.

"Ooohhh!" they whine, "That's soooo hard!"

They'd much rather try an ascent on K2, or be any kind of workaholic.

Not that I'm feeling sour grapes; I'm in a relationship I love with a man who lived a full rock and roll lifestyle for over 5 years (on the road with a famous rock singer.)

I realize men's whining about monogamy is something of a side effect of testosterone; I just don't have that much sympathy for it.

All of these comments prove one cogent thing:  if you dig hard enough, in many cases you will come up with something very, very interesting. What does not surprise me is that most of the people involved in this are not doing it for monetary value. Although my sister-in-law is much more adept than I at this sort of thing, I have always been interested in the genealogy both on my father's and mother's side of our family.

Marriage is founded up economic inequality and the raging hormones of youth, and fidelity has been the prescription for the weaker, female side.

More women, economically empowered and now electing to have families without marriage, provide their children the stability of primal permanence that marriage never can.

With economic equality we are coming to witness not just changing ideas monogamy vs. infidelity, but changing ideas, but changing ideas what constitutes a family.

Intimacy and love, if genuine, result in the desire to be faithful.  Few men and women experience the absolute joy of wanting to have a monogamous relationship, and nothing else.  For those who do, they have the chance to rewrite history.  And nothing on earth is more seductive than that (or more rewarding.)

Dan Savage speaks truth again. Given the massive divorce rate and the massive rates of non-consensual infidelity we are clearly not so great at monogamy. If we set this up the primary standard of success we are going to have a huge number of failed relationships because we define getting a little sexual variety as an inherent existential threat to our relationships.

This does require a new way of thinking, but getting out of the mold relationships as being zero-sum is a great step forward. Well done NY Times!

What I'm about to say will reveal my zoology training, but one of the functions of sex, especially for human primates, is to build and maintain a pair bond. Offspring do better when there are two adults involved in their care and rearing. That we humans are sexually receptive year round rather than seasonally supports that notion, keeps the males interested and around and keeps them tied to their mate. Sure, there is genetic evidence that it's not all Leave It To Beaver land out there, but the fact is there is an emotional bond created with sex, perhaps more on the female's part. It's why I never bought into the free love of the sixties when I was a young adult---it did matter to me and I saw plenty of my women friends hurt by trying to emulate the promiscuity of our men friends who professed to be having the time of their lives but who in fact admitted later to feeling pretty empty about the fly by night couplings.

If you want an open relationship and your partner wants that to, I'm not going to stop you. But I am going to doubt that one of you is telling the truth.

Savage makes some sense. Openness about sexual fantasies within a marriage, for example, is a good idea; infidelity is often prompted by a lack of it. But the thrust of his argument is actually nonsensical. He contends that “given the [high] rates of infidelity, people who get married should have to swear a blood oath that if it [the marriage] is violated, as traumatic as that would be, the greater good is the relationship." This statement can't survive its own unpacking. Because people are unfaithful in large numbers, it argues, they should replace the traditional marriage vow (to be faithful) with a new one: to permit one another to be unfaithful. That is, we should redefine marriage! (Oh my God, the conservatives are right!) The ostensible appeal of the argument is the appearance of its squaring up with human/sexual nature. But it fails entirely on just that score. How many men neglect to stray precisely because their wives would send them packing for doing so? How many more men (to take just men) would cheat on their wives if the get-out-of-jail-free "blood oath" proposed by Savage were the new norm? Many more, quite obviously. Anyone comfortable with evading that reality by defining infidelity out of marriage hasn't reached their position by argument, but by nomenclature. Thus, Savage argues, "the relationship" must be placed above violations of the marriage. It's "the greater good." But surely violations of the marriage just are violations of the relationship! This is to argue: "You must put up with my betrayal of our relationship for the sake of our relationship." Talk about blaming the victim. The onus is now on the person who honored the relationship to tolerate (indeed, to swear a blood oath to tolerate) the antics of the person who dishonored it--all in the name of the relationship itself. I am willing to hear the case for more flexibility in sexual norms within marriage, but I'm still waiting to hear it.

Where do the writer's comments about premarital counseling come from? He makes assumptions that all premarital counselors are clergy and that they seek to somehow fool couples about their future rather than prepare them for a lifelong marriage. Today couples have access to excellent, realistic premarital counseling where they will learn to deal with the inevitable reality that marriage involves dealing with differences and with attraction to others. http://www.therapistnyc.com
